perturbation.changed_text: Prime will use its best efforts, during the term of the Credit Agreement, to maintain some level of liquidity. The determination of the minimum liquidity required will be at the sole discretion of Prime. To the extent that shareholder repayment has occurred, Prime may consider funding additional shareholder loans as it deems necessary.
perturbation.explanation: The original text defines a specific liquidity requirement ($25,000,000) and a mechanism for adjustments. The modified text removes the specific requirement, stating 'some level of liquidity' and gives Prime sole discretion over the minimum amount and funding of additional shareholder loans, contradicting the original commitment to maintain a defined liquidity level.

perturbation.changed_text: This Agreement shall remain in force for a period of five years, unless otherwise extended by mutual agreement of all parties. Prime's warranty to Guaranty regarding funding of costs for Project Completion shall expire at the discretion of Guaranty, regardless of whether each component is satisfied.
perturbation.explanation: The original text clearly states the agreement ends when project completion is satisfied and the warranty expires at that time. The modified text introduces a fixed term (five years) and allows the warranty to expire at Guaranty's discretion, regardless of project completion, directly contradicting the original trigger for termination.

perturbation.changed_text: As an expression of good faith, Prime may consider providing funds to Offshore for costs exceeding commitments. Prime's obligation is conditional on Prime's financial condition and other business considerations. In the event Offshore is in Default under Section 7.1(f), (g), (h) and/or (i) of the Credit Agreement, Prime may, at its sole discretion, consider providing support.
perturbation.explanation: The original text clearly states an 'absolute and unconditional' warranty from Prime. The modified text replaces this with a conditional and discretionary commitment, significantly weakening Prime's obligation and contradicting the original absolute guarantee. The terms 'may consider providing' and 'at its sole discretion' introduce uncertainty and negate the original intent.
